The terms <s>term<\s> <u>cleavage<u\> & <u>foliation<u\> are
here used nearly as they have been defined by Professor
Sedgwick* & Mr. Darwin (p. 141). <u>Cleavage<\u> or <u>lamina-
tion<\u> being applied to planes of division along which
a rock may be split into thin parallel sheets
independent of, & usually transverse to it's strati-
fication. <u>Foliation<\u> describes the division of rocks
believed to be of crystalline origin into layers of
different mineral substances, whether the rock
splits along those layers as in Mica Schist, forms
a solid rock as in the granitic varieties of Gneiss,
or consists of distinct sheets of different materials,
such as Quartz, Mica, Chlorite, &c which sheets may
be of any thickness, from a line up to one or two feet,
as may be seen both in the "Laminar Gneiss” & 'Chlorite Schist series' of Macculloch. For the sake of clearness
the term <u>Slate<\u> is here confined to laminated rocks with
a cleavage independent of their stratification, & <u>Schist<\u> to foliated rocks with only one set of divisional
surfaces produced by the foliation. The distinctions
between foliation & stratification, which Macculloch
& many subsequent Authors have confounded,
